The amount of your loan that is forgiven under the PSLF program is not taxable income. If you are struggling to make your loan payments or find it difficult to stay current on your loans, you may want to consider applying for an income-driven repayment plan to have your monthly payments based on your income. These plans can lower your payments and potentially reduce your total loan balance over time. To get started, you can fill out the Income-Driven Repayment Plan Request form, which is available through your loan servicer's online system. Once you submit the application, your servicer will review it and determine if you are eligible for an income-driven repayment plan based on your income and family size. If approved, you will be assigned an IDR plan to choose from, and your servicer will review your income and family size annually to ensure that you continue to qualify for the plan. If not, your servicer will place you on an alternative repayment plan, which may not take into account your income or family size.

If you've filed a disability benefits claim with the VA, you may be asked to have a compensation and pension (C&P) exam. Here's what you need to know about the VA claim exam, including why it's needed and how to schedule your appointment.

Why Might I Need a VA Claim Exam?
A VA claim exam will help the VA rate your disability, which will affect your disability compensation. The exam will determine the severity of your disability and help the VA understand how to support your claim.

Does Everyone Who Files a Claim Need to Have a VA Claim Exam?
No, the VA may not ask for a claim exam if you have enough medical evidence in your file to support your claim. Medical evidence includes doctor and hospital reports, test results, and other documents.

How to Schedule Your VA Claim Exam
The staff at your local VA medical center or a local doctor's office that we partner with will contact you. They will either send you a letter by mail with the date and time of your exam, or call you to find a time that works for you. Be sure to have all the information about your claim ready, including medical records and any new non-VA medical records.

What to Expect at Your VA Claim Exam
You don't need to bring anything to your exam. If you have any new non-VA medical records, please make sure to submit them before your appointment. The health care provider can't review new information during the exam. During your exam, the doctor may do any or all of these things: Review your claim file with you; Ask you questions based on the medical records in your claim file; Take a look at the Disability Benefits Questionnaires (DBQs); Perform a basic physical exam; Ask you to get other tests, like X-rays or blood work, if needed.

After Your VA Claim Exam
After your exam, the doctor will write up a report and send it to a VA claims processor to be added to your claim file. Your exam may be very short, or it may last an hour or more, depending on the conditions you claim and whether we need more information to make a decision.

Does Everyone Who Files a Claim Need to Have a VA Claim Exam?
No, we'll ask you to have a claim exam if we need more information to decide your claim. If you have enough medical evidence in your file to support your claim, we won't ask you to have a claim exam. Veterans can also have their own doctors examine them and fill out the necessary forms.

I hope this information helps you understand the VA claim exam process and what to expect. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to contact the VA.

How Much Work Do You Need?
In addition to meeting our definition of disability, you must have worked long enough and recently enough under Social Security to qualify for disability benefits. Social Security work credits are based on your total yearly wages or self-employment income. To earn credits, you must earn at least $1,360 in wages or self-employment income each year. The number of work credits you need depends on your age when you become disabled. Generally, you need 40 credits, 20 of which were earned in the last 10 years preceding your disability. However, younger workers may qualify with fewer credits. For more information and a calculation tool, visit our publication, How You Earn Credits.

What We Mean By Disability?
The definition of disability under Social Security is different from other programs. Under Social Security, we pay only for total disability. No benefits are payable for partial disability or short-term disability. We consider you disabled if you cannot do work that you did before, if you cannot adjust to other work because of your medical condition, and if your disability has lasted or is expected to last for at least one year or to result in death. This is a strict definition of disability. Social Security program rules assume that working families have access to other resources to provide support during periods of short-term disabilities. These include workers' compensation, insurance, savings, and investments.

How We Decide If You Are Disabled
To determine if you are disabled, we follow a five-step process. Step 1: Are you working? If you are working and your earnings average more than $1,220 a month, you generally cannot be considered disabled. If you are not working, we will send your application to the Disability Determination Services (DDS) office that will make the decision about your medical condition. The DDS will use our five steps to make the decision.

Step 2: Is your condition severe? Your condition must significantly limit your ability to do basic work such as lifting, standing, walking, sitting, and remembering for at least 12 months. If it does not, we will find that you are not disabled. If your condition does interfere with basic work-related activities, we go to Step 3.

Step 3: Is your condition found in the list of disabling conditions? For each major body system, we maintain a list of medical conditions that we consider so severe that it prevents a person from completing substantial gainful activity. If your condition is not on the list, we have to decide if it is as severe as a medical condition that is on the list. If it is, we will find that you are disabled. If it is not, we then go to Step 4.

Step 4: Can you do the work you did previously? At this step, we decide if your medical impairment prevents you from performing any of your past work. It does not. We proceed to Step 5.
